metadata.title: Influence of NiO-calcination on Pt-supported catalyst for selective oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural

Influence of NiO-calcination on Pt-supported catalyst for selective oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural Hao Zhang Investigation Methodology Formal analysis Writing – original draft a Botao Fan Investigation Formal analysis a Longchun Bian Resources Supervision a ⁎ Qinghu Tang Funding acquisition b Qiue Cao Resources a Wenhao Fang Conceptualization Resources Supervision Writing – review & editing Project administration Funding acquisition a ⁎ a School of Chemical Science and Technology, Yunnan University, 2 North Cuihu Road, 650091 Kunming, China School of Chemical Science and Technology Yunnan University 2 North Cuihu Road Kunming 650091 China School of Chemical Science and Technology, Yunnan University, 2 North Cuihu Road, 650091 Kunming, China. b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Collaborative Innovation Center of Henan Province for Green Manufacturing of Fine Chemicals, Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Media and Reactions, Ministry of Education, Henan Normal University, 453007 Xinxiang, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Collaborative Innovation Center of Henan Province for Green Manufacturing of Fine Chemicals, Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Media and Reactions, Ministry of Education Henan Normal University Xinxiang 453007 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Collaborative Innovation Center of Henan Province for Green Manufacturing of Fine Chemicals, Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Media and Reactions, Ministry of Education, Henan Normal University, 453007 Xinxiang, China. ⁎ Corresponding authors. The calcination temperature (400–600 °C) of NiO was modulated and then the support effect on a Pt-supported catalyst was studied for the base-free aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid. Various characterizations revealed that NiO calcined at 400 °C showed a mesoporous structure, a largest specific area (89 m2 g−1), abundant reactive oxygen species (55.1 mmol g−1). Therefore, the corresponding Pt/Ni 400c catalyst enabled 100% selectivity of FDCA at 100% conversion of HMF in water under 10 bar of O2, 100 °C and 12 h. The role of different oxygen species in NiO for transforming HMF and the intermediates was elucidated. Graphical abstract Unlabelled Image Keywords Aerobic oxidation Biomass conversion Calcination temperature Nickel oxide Pt nanoparticles Reactive oxygen species Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nickel oxide (NiO) as a typical p-type semiconductor has been widely used in batteries [1], capacitors [2], sensors [3], fuel cells [4] and catalysis [5–7]. Generally, the high catalytic performance of a metal oxide catalyst can be related to its morphology, structure, and redox property [8,9]. For instance, a mesoporous structure, large specific surface area and pore volume can be probably beneficial to an enhanced catalytic activity. H. Wang et al. reported a mesoporous NiO prepared from a templated method for the catalytic oxidation of formaldehyde [10], and the high catalytic results were attributed to the ordered mesopores that led to defective sites and abundant active oxygen species on the surface of catalyst. Hence, NiO nanoparticles with a high specific surface area and a uniform structure (i.e., grain size and pore diameter) are promising for catalytic oxidation reactions. M. Ramesh et al. investigated the effect of annealing temperature of NiO nanoparticles on the adsorption performance and photocatalytic activity for degradation of methylene blue [11]. It was found that the catalytic property was significantly influenced by the grain size of NiO caused by different annealing temperatures. In addition, S. Wu et al. demonstrated that the calcination temperature could also give rise to an obvious effect on the structure, redox and other properties of an oxide in oxidation catalysis [12]. Thereby, tuning the calcination temperature of NiO is likely to be an effective and doable approach to optimize its catalytic property. As shown in Scheme 1 , the catalytically aerobic oxidation of HMF which can be obtained from dehydration of fructose or glucose to FDCA is a desirable and feasible route to using the lignocellulosic biomass [13–15]. FDCA can be used as a building-block chemical for production of the renewable bio-based polyesters [16]. In the literature, noble metals (i.e., Au, Pd, Pt, Ru) as heterogeneous catalysts have been reported as highly active and selective catalysts for aerobic oxidation HMF to FDCA with the addition of base additives [17–20]. However, the addition of alkali to catalytic system results in extra cost for purification and isolation of product. It has been shown that using the transition metal oxide catalyst with abundant reactive oxygen species can offer an effectively base-free approach for FDCA synthesis from HMF [21,22]. Herein, this work reports a Pt/NiO catalyst that exhibits the superior catalytic behavior for the base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA with molecular oxygen as oxidant and water as solvent. ICP-MS, TEM, XRD, N2 physisorption, H2-TPR, O2-TPD, XPS and EPR are used to analyze the catalytic property of a Pt/NiO catalyst. The effect of calcination temperature of NiO on structure, morphology, and redox property is elucidated. On the basis of results from catalytic reactions and characterizations, the catalytic performances can be mainly correlated to the different oxygen species on the surface of catalyst, which can be decisive for the conversion rate of HMF and the intermediates. This finding may provide some insights into design and optimization of an oxide catalyst for oxidation reactions. 2 Experimental sections 2.1 Materials and reagents H2PtCl6·6H2O (> 38% on Pt basis), Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (98%), NaBH4 (> 98%) and NaOH (98%) were obtained from Alfa Aesar. Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP, > 98%, M.W. = 10,000) was supplied by Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF, 98%), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA, 98%), 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF, 98%), 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA, 98%) and 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA, 98%) were obtained from Ark Pharm for catalytic reactions. 2.2 Catalyst preparation NiO support was synthesized by the precipitation method. Typically, a certain amount of Ni salt (2.89 g) and 100 mL of deionized water were firstly mixed, and then the pH value of mixture was adjusted to 9 with addition of a NaOH solution of 1 mol L−1. The slurry was kept stirring (600 rpm) at 25 °C for 24 h and then the resultant green solids were filtrated and washed with enough deionized water until the filtrate presented a pH value of 7. The solids were subsequently oven-dried at 110 °C for 12 h and Ni(OH)2 was obtained. Finally, Ni(OH)2 was calcined at different temperatures (i.e., 400, 500 and 600 °C, with a ramp of 2 °C min−1) under air flow for 4 h. The as-prepared NiO supports were named as Ni Tc , i.e., Ni 400c , Ni 500c , and Ni 600c , respectively. Pt/Ni Tc catalyst with a theoretical Pt loading of 1 wt% was prepared by a PVP-assisted adsorption method. Typically, H2PtCl6·6H2O, PVP (PVP/Pt = 1, in weight) and 60 mL of deionized water were mixed under a stirring (600 rpm) for 30 min. Where after, the NiO support was added and the mixture was continuously stirred for 1 h. A fresh NaBH4 solution (NaBH4/Pt = 5/1, in mole) was added dropwise and then the suspension was stirred for another 2 h. The filtration was used to separate the solids which were washed by excessive hot and cold water for removing PVP, Na+ and Cl− ions. Lastly, the Pt/Ni Tc catalyst was obtained after a desiccation treatment under vacuum at 80 °C for 12 h. 2.3 Characterization methods In situ XRD in air flow was performed on a Bruker D8 Advance type HT1200N X-ray diffractometer equipped with a fast detector type VANTEC with a copper anticathode. The sample was loaded into a quartz capillary cell that was attached to a flow system (flow rate: 10 mL min−1, heating rate: 10 °C min−1) and the pattern was collected during temperature rise (200, 300, 400, 500 and 600 °C). The Pt loading of catalysts was determined by ICP-MS on an Agilent 7500a apparatus. The samples were analyzed after dissolution by chloroazotic acid and dilution by deionized water. TEM measurements of catalysts were performed on a Philips-FET TECNAI F30 field emission electron microscope with an acceleration voltage of 300 kV. The samples was firstly added into ethanol and dispersed by assistance of ultrasonic wave. Several drops of suspension were supported on a lacey support film. The textural property of NiO was analyzed at 77 K on a V-Sorb 4800 specific surface area and pore size analyzer from Chinainstru & Quantumtech (Hefei) Co., Ltd. BET and BJH methods were used. Before analysis, the sample was treated at 180 °C for 3 h. A Micromeritics Autochem II Chemisorption Analyzer was used to perform H2-TPR and O2-TPD. For TPR, the samples were pretreated with a 5% H2/95% Ar (in volume) mixed gas with a flow velocity of 30 mL min−1 for 30 min. And the TPR profile was recorded from 50 to 800 °C (10 °C min−1). For TPD, the samples were treated in an Ar flow at 200 °C for 30 min and then cooled to 50 °C. Then a 5% O2/95% Ar (in volume) mixed gas with a flow rate of 30 mL min−1 was introduced into the reactor for 60 min. An Ar flow was switched for 30 min in order to purge the gas phase O2 in the reactor. And then the TPD profile was recorded from 50 to 800 °C in Ar flow. Low-temperature EPR spectra were collected at 100 K on an A300 Bruker EPR spectrometer. The X-band frequencies, standard modulation amplitude and field modulation frequency were 9.4 GHz, 1.0-G and 100 kHz, respectively. The DPPH (i.e., 1,1-diphenyl-2-picrylhydrazyl) standard was used for the quantitative calculation. A Thermo Scientific Escalab 250Xi system with an Al Kα radiation was applied to XPS analysis in ultra-high vacuum. The binding energy shift due to surface charging was adjusted by a reference of the C 1s line at 284.5 eV. 2.4 Catalytic reaction The oxidation reaction of HMF was tested using a batch-type Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave. In a typical procedure, a certain amount of catalyst (HMF/Pt = 200, in mole), 20 mL of deionized water and 1 mmol of HMF were added into the reactor. Subsequently, O2 was introduced and degassed for three times and the pressure was kept at 10 bar. The reactor was then put in an oil bath at 100 °C under stirring (600 rpm) for 12 h. Finally, the reactor was moved to an ice bath for rapid cooling. An Agilent 1260 Infinity HPLC apparatus equipped with a photodiode array detector and a Shodex SH-1011 sugar column (8 mm × 300 mm × 6 μm) was used to analyze the reaction mixture. A diluted H2SO4 solution of 0.5 mM was used as the mobile phase. The quantification was based on an external standard method. Every reaction was repeated with an error of ±1%. Carbon balance of each reaction was calculated and the data reached 99–100%. The following equations were used to calculate the conversion, initial reaction rate and selectivity. Conv . % = n reactant , 0 − n reactant , t n reactant , 0 × 100 % Initial reaction rate mmol mol Pt − 1 s − 1 = n reactant , 0 − n reactant , t n Pt × time Select . % = n product n reactant , 0 − n reactant , t × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and structure Temperature-programed XRD was carried out to analyze the structural evolution of Ni(OH)2 precursor in an air flow from room temperature up to 600 °C (Fig. 1 ). The XRD patterns of Ni(OH)2 from 25 to 200 °C present six diffraction peaks at 19.3°, 33.1°, 38.5°, 52.1°, 59.0° and 62.7°, which can be well assigned to the (001), (100), (101), (102), (110) and (111) planes of β-Ni(OH)2 (JCPDS #14–0117) [23]. When the temperature reaches and exceeds 400 °C, only NiO peaks can be observed and ascribed to the cubic NiO phase (JCPDS #47–1049) [24]. Notably, the diffraction peaks recorded at 300 °C exhibits a mixed phase of β-Ni(OH)2 and cubic NiO, which indicates a phase transformation from Ni(OH)2 to NiO [25]. And the diffraction peaks become narrower and stronger with increasing the temperature from 400 to 600 °C, which suggests an increasing grain size (17.6 to 35.7 nm) of NiO (Table S1). This reveals that a pure NiO phase is obtained by calcination treatment of Ni(OH)2 at ≥400 °C and a higher calcination temperature leads to bigger nanoparticles of NiO. N2 physisorption was performed to analyze the textural property of the bare support. As shown in Fig. 2 , the Ni Tc supports present a type IV isotherm with a H1 hysteresis loop and a relatively symmetrical pore size distribution. These indicate the presence of well mesoporous structure [26,27]. As listed in Table 1 , a higher calcination temperature of Ni Tc supports can lead to a lower specific surface area and average pore volume but a bigger pore diameter. This can be related to the increasing grain size of NiO (Table S1), which is well consistent with XRD results. The Ni 400c support shows the highest specific surface area (89 m2 g−1) and average pore volume (0.14 cm3 g−1), which may be probably conducive to the catalytic reaction [28]. ICP-MS was used to determine the actual Pt loadings in the catalyst. The measured values (0.96–0.98 wt%) of the Pt/Ni Tc catalysts are very close to the theoretical loading of Pt (1 wt%), which reveals an effective immobilization of Pt species on Ni Tc supports during catalyst preparation (Table 1). TEM was carried out to inspect the morphology of the catalyst. The representative Pt/Ni 400c and Pt/Ni 600c catalysts show high dispersions of Pt nanoparticles, which display a narrow size distribution (1–5 nm) and a similar mean size of ca. 3.0 nm (Fig. 3 ). Moreover, NiO particles present a thin-layered morphology and Ni 600c is clearly observed to show bigger particle size. This is in agreement with XRD analysis. TEM images indicate that the size of Pt nanoparticles may be independent of NiO upon calcination. The size effect of Pt nanoparticles on the catalytic activity may be excluded. 3.2 Redox property H2-TPR and O2-TPD were performed to investigate the redox property of the Ni Tc supports. As displayed in Fig. 4 A, Ni 400c shows a main reduction peak at ca. 309 °C, which can be due to the reduction of NiO [29,30]. The asymmetric reduction peaks indicates the sequential reduction of Ni3+ and Ni2+ ions presented in NiO [31]. And the reduction peaks are found to shift to a higher temperature (309 to 334 °C) as the calcination temperature rises (400 to 600 °C), which can be attributed to the increasing grain size of NiO. This is also in good agreement with XRD and TEM results. Thereby, the result reveals an enhanced reductive ability of NiO obtained in a lower calcination temperature. O2-TPD profiles of the Ni Tc supports show three types of oxygen species (Fig. 4B). The desorption peak at ca. 155 °C can be assigned to the O2 molecules (O2, ads.) weakly adsorbed on NiO [32]. The broad desorption band of 200–700 °C can be classified into two parts. The brand at 200–470 °C can be ascribed to the defective oxygen species (Oads., O2 − and O−) associated with oxygen vacancies, and the band above 470 °C can be attributed to the lattice oxygen species (Olatt.) in NiO [31]. The desorption peaks of Oads. and Olatt. species of the Ni Tc supports are observed to slightly shift to higher temperature when the calcination temperature increases. The quantitative analysis discloses that three types of oxygen species on the Ni Tc supports all decrease with increasing calcination temperature (Table S2). Notably, Ni 400c shows the abundant reactive oxygen species (Oads. and Olatt.) bearing a concentration of 55.1 mmol g−1, and the desorption peaks are located in a lower temperature domain, which are indicative of an enhanced oxygen mobility. This observation is well consistent with H2-TPR results. Following that, low-temperature EPR and XPS were further used to deeply analyze the redox property of the Ni Tc supports. Low-temperature EPR is a powerful technique to directly observe and measure the oxygen vacancy related to defective oxygen species in an oxide. The typical and symmetric EPR signal due to oxygen vacancies is clearly obtained at ca. 3515 G with a g-value of 2.003 (Fig. 4C) [33]. The quantitative data show that the concentration of oxygen vacancies on Ni 400c is of 11.9 × 1016 spins g−1 (Fig. 4D), which is obviously higher than that of Ni 500c (8.8 × 1016 spins g−1) and Ni 600c (7.5 × 1016 spins g−1). EPR results reveal that a lower calcination temperature can retain an abundant oxygen vacancies on NiO, but which would be largely reduced in the presence of a higher calcination temperature. The existence of oxygen vacancies on NiO can induce the generation of abundant defective oxygen species in NiO, which is in agreement with O2-TPD analysis. The XPS spectra of Pt 4f, Ni 2p and O 1s core levels of the representative Pt/Ni 400c and Pt/Ni 600c catalysts were compared (Fig. 5 ). XPS spectra of the Pt 4f 5/2 and Pt 4f 7/2 regions can be resolved into four peaks that can be due to Pt0 (71.7 and 75.4 eV) and Pt2+ (73.2 and 76.3 eV) species [34,35], respectively. The Ni 2p 3/2 core level can be fitted into three peaks [36]. The peaks located at ca. 853.7 and 860.0 eV can be assigned to Ni2+ ions and its satellite peaks, respectively. The peak observed at ca. 855.6 eV can be ascribed to Ni3+ ions. Specially, Pt/Ni 400c exhibits a lower binding energy for Pt0 but a higher value for Ni2+ in comparison with the Pt/Ni 600c catalyst (Table S3). This can be caused by the electron transfer from Pt nanoparticles to NiO support, which indicates the presence of a strong metal-support interaction. The XPS spectra of O 1s line exhibit two peaks with binding energies at ca. 529.4 and 531.3 eV, which can be severally attributed to the lattice oxygen species (Olatt., O2−) and the defective oxygen species (O2 − and O−) associated with oxygen vacancies [37]. In addition, the quantitative results shows that the fractions of Pt0 (65%), Ni2+ (39%) and Olatt. (63%) of the Pt/Ni 400c catalyst are similar to that of Pt/Ni 600c (Table S3), which suggests that the effect of calcination temperature on the surface composition of catalyst may be disregarded. 3.3 Discussion on the structure-activity relationship The Pt/Ni Tc catalysts were tested for aerobic oxidation of HMF under mild conditions (i.e., 100 °C, 12 h) with no base additives (Table 2 ). The Pt/Ni 400c catalyst shows the highest conversion of HMF (100%) with a selectivity of FDCA at 100%. When the calcination temperature of NiO increases, conversion of HMF over the Pt/Ni Tc catalysts can maintain at 100% but selectivity of FDCA is found to decline from 100% to 63%. Meanwhile, FFCA rises from zero to 37%. Notably, the bare Ni 400c support shows a rather low conversion of HMF (25%) and trace of selectivity of FDCA (1%). This implies that Pt nanoparticles are an essential and active component for the base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA. The reactions during the initial stage over the Pt/Ni Tc catalysts were conducted to monitor the intrinsic activity (Table S4). The results show a different product distribution related to the calcination temperature of NiO. When conversion of HMF is kept at ca. 28% (i.e., within the kinetic-controlled region), selectivity of FDCA is found to decline (7% to 5%) with increasing calcination temperature. Meanwhile, selectivity of DFF exhibits an increase (56% to 65%) and that of FFCA maintains at 6%. These results clearly reveal that aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA undergoes a multistep reaction pathway and conversion of HMF to DFF is the major route (Scheme 1). And the calcination temperature of NiO shows a different effect on the conversion rates of HMF and the intermediates. The initial reaction rates of HMF, DFF, HMFCA and FFCA were precisely measured over the Pt/Ni Tc catalysts and reported in Table 3 . The reaction rates of HMF and each individual intermediate all reach the highest values over the Pt/Ni 400c catalyst and a declining trend is observed at a higher calcination temperature of NiO. Notably, the initial reaction rate of DFF for the Pt/Ni Tc catalyst is the highest and that of FFCA is the lowest, which indicates that the rate-limiting step can be oxidation of FFCA to FDCA (Scheme 1). A higher calcination temperature leads to a decline of reaction rate for HMF and the intermediates, which may be probably due to the decrease of reactive oxygen species on the surface of catalyst. Based on the characterization results and the catalytic performances, it can be reasonable to elucidate the effect of calcination temperature of NiO on the Pt/Ni Tc catalyst in the base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA. As plotted in Fig. 6 , the initial reaction rates of HMF and the intermediates are found to be well correlated to the amount of reactive oxygen species (Oads. and Olatt.) and the concentration of oxygen vacancies. The amount of reactive oxygen species and oxygen vacancies in the Ni Tc supports exhibits a decrease with increasing the calcination temperature. However, reactive oxygen species and oxygen vacancies have been confirmed to play an important role in aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA. The Pt/Ni 400c catalyst shows the highest surface area that may lead to more defective sites and abundant oxygen vacancies on the surface of catalyst, which is key and essential to adsorb O2 and then generate reactive oxygen species. 4 Conclusions In summary, the effect of calcination temperature of NiO support on the catalytic performances of the Pt/Ni Tc catalysts was elaborated for the base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA. Different calcination temperatures resulted in an obvious effect on the structural, texural and redox properties of NiO support. When the calcination temperature of NiO was of 400 °C, the obtained mesoprous NiO supproted-Pt catalyst presented a largest specific surface area, a smallest grain size of NiO, and abundant reactive oxygen species and oxygen vacancies. These features can be conductive to adsorb and activate O2 and reactants, which was then beneficial to the high catalytic activity for the base-free aerobic oxidation of HMF to FDCA. coredata.dc:description: The calcination temperature (400–600 °C) of NiO was modulated and then the support effect on a Pt-supported catalyst was studied for the base-free aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid. Various characterizations revealed that NiO calcined at 400 °C showed a mesoporous structure, a largest specific area (89 m2 g−1), abundant reactive oxygen species (55.1 mmol g−1). Therefore, the corresponding Pt/Ni 400c catalyst enabled 100% selectivity of FDCA at 100% conversion of HMF in water under 10 bar of O2, 100 °C and 12 h. The role of different oxygen species in NiO for transforming HMF and the intermediates was elucidated.
coredata.dc:title: Influence of NiO-calcination on Pt-supported catalyst for selective oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural
